perturbation.original_text: The Customer is responsible for paying the recurring monthly fee in the amount of $450. The Customer is responsible for paying the recurring monthly fees by the 5th day of each month beginning in April 1, 1999.

perturbation.explanation: Changing the payment due date to the 25th of the month could potentially violate Florida Statutes regarding late payment fees if the contract does not adequately address grace periods and penalties, contradicting laws that protect consumers from unreasonable penalties.

perturbation.original_text: This Agreement shall automatically be renewed for one (1) or more one (1) month periods unless either the Customer or i-on gives notice to the other party of its intention not to renew the Agreement, which notice must be given not less than fifteen (15) days before the end of the respective initial or renewal term.
perturbation.changed_text: This Agreement shall automatically be renewed for one (1) or more one (1) month periods unless either the Customer or i-on gives notice to the other party of its intention not to renew the Agreement, which notice must be given not less than five (5) days before the end of the respective initial or renewal term.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the notification period for non-renewal to 5 days might violate Florida's automatic renewal laws for certain contracts, which often require a longer notice period to protect consumers from unwanted renewals.
perturbation.law_explanation: The modified text shortens the notice period for non-renewal to 5 days, which is likely insufficient under Florida's automatic renewal statute § 559.221, requiring longer notice periods to prevent automatic renewals in certain types of contracts, potentially deceiving the consumer.

perturbation.original_text: Either party may terminate this Agreement without cause at any time effective upon thirty (30) days' written notice.
perturbation.changed_text: Either party may terminate this Agreement without cause at any time effective upon ten (10) days' written notice.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the termination notice period to ten (10) days could be deemed unreasonable or insufficient, conflicting with general contract law principles which often require a reasonable notice period that allows the other party adequate time to make alternative arrangements, given the nature of web hosting services.
perturbation.law_explanation: Florida Statute § 671.309(2) states that an action is taken seasonably when it is taken at or within the time agreed or, if no time is agreed, at or within a reasonable time. Reducing the notification of termination to ten days may be deemed an 'unreasonable time,' and therefore contradicts state law.
